Stress can lower your resistance to bugs, but not exactly cause your skin to burn.If you feel that all your skin on your body feels like burning, and you haven't been sunbathing or had exposure to any irritants, it is likely to be due to a fever either from a bacterial or viral infection.Depending on your age, if you are on starting the change of life that can make you feel very hot, called hot flushes sometimes referred to as hot flashes.Another reason why certain parts of the skin may feel like burning is if you suffer from diabetes and have peripheral nerve damage.Have a cool bath or shower to cool down the skin and don't use any soaps that may irritate and dry the skin.Best wishes.

You can be eating something for years without any problems and then suddenly become allergic to it.For your burning and itching skin like your doctor says, may be from an allergy to food.  Sometimes we can get itchy and burning skin from diabetes and some blood disorders and from dry skin.  The skin dries as we age.  You may even have an allergy to your soaps, perfumes and detergents.  Use non-biological washing detergents and only use fabric softeners suitable for sensitive skin.  Don't use perfumed and harsh soaps.If your rash does not go away, go back to your doctor.  An antihistamine may help and the doctor may recommend a bath emollient for you to use and an antibacterial cream for your rash if this is not allergy related.Best wishes.

You should see your doctor like I suggested in my previous reply to you.Swelling can be from a number of different causes, so you should tell your doctor about this too.  Depends where the swelling is.  If in your feet this can be from poor blood circulation, kidney or heart conditions, that is why you need to go back and see your doctor.You do not need to have any rashes on the skin for there to be a problem.  Rashes on the skin can be from internal or external allergies and problems.  But underlying skin problems like swelling and feeling hot can be from other causes.  The doctor may check your blood pressure and may prescribe diuretics if there is a lot of fluid retention that is causing the swelling.If the swelling is caused by arthritic problems this needs to be treated differently.  Pins and needles need to be investigated to rule out any underlying problem.  Stress, anxiety and depression can exacerbate any problem.
